prior_works.title: Annealed Importance Sampling
prior_works.role: Canonical annealing-based estimator for normalizing constants; defines the multi-temperature/path framework and IS weights used as the baseline.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s core comparison of annealed estimators is anchored in Neal’s AIS; it quantifies AIS’s asymptotic error and contrasts it with NCE, and analyzes how step size and path choice affect AIS efficiency.

prior_works.title: Noise-Contrastive Estimation of Unnormalized Statistical Models, with Applications to Natural Image Statistics
prior_works.role: Introduces NCE as a discriminative method that simultaneously estimates parameters and the normalizing constant.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The authors analyze NCE specifically as a partition-function estimator, proving it is asymptotically more efficient than IS and characterizing how annealing (multiple intermediate contrasts) impacts its error.

prior_works.title: Simulating Normalizing Constants: From Importance Sampling to Bridge Sampling to Path Sampling
prior_works.role: Establishes the general path-sampling/thermodynamic integration framework linking IS, bridge sampling, and annealed paths.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work motivates evaluating design choices along a continuum from IS to path-based methods; the new paper formalizes asymptotic error along paths and shows why annealing can dramatically reduce error.

prior_works.title: Marginal Likelihood Estimation via Power Posteriors
prior_works.role: Introduces and popularizes the geometric (power posterior) path for estimating normalizing constants via thermodynamic integration.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The geometric path studied here traces directly to power posteriors; the paper proves this path yields superior asymptotic error—reducing scaling from exponential to polynomial under broad conditions.

prior_works.title: Simulating Ratios of Normalizing Constants via a Simple Identity (Bridge Sampling)
prior_works.role: Develops bridge sampling and the idea of using optimal bridges to estimate ratios of normalizing constants.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By connecting discriminative estimators to bridge ideas, this prior work underpins why carefully chosen intermediate distributions (or bridges) outperform plain IS, a principle the paper extends to annealed NCE vs IS.

prior_works.title: Efficient Estimation of Free Energy Differences from Monte Carlo Data (Bennett Acceptance Ratio)
prior_works.role: Introduces the optimal two-sample estimator for free-energy differences, closely related to logistic/contrastive formulations.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The efficiency gap the paper proves between NCE and IS parallels Bennett’s optimal ratio-estimation vs naive IS, highlighting how discriminative/logistic-style estimators can attain lower asymptotic error.

prior_works.title: Estimating Normalizing Constants and Reweighting in Markov Chain Monte Carlo (Reverse Logistic Regression)
prior_works.role: Proposes reverse logistic regression for estimating ratios of normalizing constants, connecting classification-based estimation with bridging.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This connection foreshadows NCE’s contrastive view; the paper leverages the same discriminative-vs-IS dichotomy to explain why NCE (and its annealed form) can be asymptotically more efficient than IS.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s contribution—provably characterizing when and why annealing improves estimation of normalizing constants and clarifying the efficiency hierarchy between NCE and importance sampling—rests on three intertwined lines of prior work. First, Neal’s annealed importance sampling established the core idea of traversing a sequence of intermediate distributions to estimate partition functions, providing the baseline estimator and design knobs (step size, schedule) that the present work rigorously analyzes. Second, the discriminative perspective inaugurated by Gutmann and Hyvärinen’s noise-contrastive estimation reframed normalizer estimation as a classification problem; earlier roots in Bennett’s acceptance ratio and Geyer’s reverse logistic regression showed that logistic/bridge-based estimators can be statistically superior to naive IS. These works directly foreshadow the paper’s result that NCE is asymptotically more efficient than IS (and that their gap vanishes with infinitesimal steps). Third, the path-design literature—bridge sampling (Meng & Wong), path/thermodynamic integration (Gelman & Meng), and power posteriors (Friel & Pettitt)—made explicit that the choice of intermediate distributions is critical. Building on this, the paper proves that the geometric (power) path is not merely convenient but can reduce error scaling from exponential to polynomial, giving a principled answer to which path one should use. Together, these strands enable a unified asymptotic error analysis that compares estimators, clarifies the role of annealing, and identifies provably good paths.
